title: Electrolysis of NaCl - evidence redox reaction

content.description:
Sodium hydroxide can be produced commercially from the electrolysis of sodium chloride solutions, as indicated by the following balanced equation.

<math alttext="2 N a C l aqueous plus 2 H 2 O liquid, react to produce 2 N a O H aqueous plus C l 2 gas, plus H 2 gas. delta G naught, equals 400 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>400</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Which of the following is the best evidence that the reaction is an oxidation-reduction reaction?

choices.label: Heat is consumed during the reaction.

The oxidation numbers of both <math alttext="N a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> change as the reaction proceeds.

The oxidation number of each <math alttext="C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom changes from <math alttext="negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and some <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms change from <math alttext="positive 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Each <math alttext="C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom gains an electron, and each <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule loses a proton.

content.answer: The oxidation number of each <math alttext="C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom changes from <math alttext="negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and some <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms change from <math alttext="positive 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
